comment: Not as spicy as other ryes. Smooth and approachable.
Gift from a friend, so always a plus! Definitely get the orange in the nose. Taste a little cinnamon and of course rye. A little heat, but not too much. Very good rye.

Orange/lemon, vanilla oak $ spice
H20> orange, rounded, oak & spice, m body, soft & smooth, oak finish
Best suited as a cocktail ingredient. When drank neat the whiskey tastes more like a raw grain spirit than aged rye whiskey.
Strong rye flavor smoothing out over the pour.
two sweet and bitter/tart?? tried a double on the rocks and I just couldn't even finish it
Great value. Not subtle, but that's not always a bad thing. My go-to for manhattans.
Best in a mixed drink, especially whiskey sour. Very woody and not complex. Not great neat
Very herbal rye, with sawdust, eucalyptus, menthol and cinammon stick notes. Little sweetness. Strong alcohol bite, which makes it a bit rough for tasting neat.
Maybe it's not subtle, but it is enjoyable.
Oaky, spicy, leathery, with a bit of herbal bitterness. It's got a bit of youthful heat, so I prefer using this in mixed drinks instead of having it neat.

An inexpensive choice for cocktails and fun to have around for comparison purposes since it's the foundation for so many other products. It's a little harsh for sipping, but I do sometimes to reset my baseline.
Definitely young. Great spicy flavor over ice for the price.
my first rye. spicy with a decent bit of heat to it. enjoyed
I have a big ice cube in here. That is all.
My first rye. Opened me up to ryes. Not sure how it holds up to other ryes. I actually enjoyed this (rye) whiskey quite a bit. Rye.
Sugary scent, fresh spice, slight sour note.  Brown sugar, rye, smooth.  Light bite.
Not a huge rye fan, but this is great. It's a little sweet once you get past the spiciness, and the mouthfeel is creamy.
Nice mix of oak and citrus on the nose. A little clove and leather flavor in the middle. It ends fairly smooth with some spice and rye.
Spice, oak and orange nose. Heat and young spicy notes on the palate with clove and golden raisin. The finish has legs and echoes burnt orange and spice. Young bottle but nice with an ice cube.

Hot on the nose but the follow through isn't quite there.  The clove taste is a bit overpowering to me.  Overall not balanced enough for straight drinking, however will be interested to use this in cocktails especially at the price point.
Liquid rye bread. Overall very fun. However, do the lack of Aging it's a bit rough
So, for this price, I give this a thumbs up. On its own, it's kind of dull, but a strong oak & rye presence makes it GREAT for mixing, & it's cheap. Makes a killer Manhattan.
Decent and probably wouldn't buy again.  Like it more as a cocktail rye when I want a spicier Old Fashioned.
For a high rye, don't get a lot of spice on palate or finish. Honestly get a little pickle.

Very good, in value, flavour, and body. Very okay, flavours of hay, wheat, and stone. A touch sweet, better on its own than in a cocktail. Really nice for the money. (Plus, the bottle is lovely!) I wouldn't put it with the best whiskeys or Bourbon, but definitely one of the best ryes I've tried (for the money, at least).
A little heat, moonshine like. Would not buy again.
Buttery smooth finish with some front end assertivness. Spicy/citrus. Good for cocktails.
Gross. Super tart and tangy at the end.
Name has changed to just Redemption bourbon.
Decent enough as a mixer, but a little solvent-y alone
Had at American Social after 3 beers. Neat it was good, definitely spicy and a little overpowering with food. 1/10/17
great for old fashioned good price.
Not nearly as spicy as other ryes, but with a strong hint of iodine on the pallet. The nose was fairly mild for a rye.
Spice, tea, and tobacco. A lot of heat
I like this straight up, for sipping. Tasty, good bite.
Surprisingly smooth. Not super spicy, but enough “rye” taste too make me smile
This is the only sourced IN rye I keep, mainly to represent the distillery on my shelf.
Rich rye spice up front followed by a lighter finish of oak, vanilla, and leather. Smooth enough to be enjoyed neat, also good for a Manhattan
with stones, brings out the rye spice and licorice that I'm not a fan of. enjoyed more at room temp. there was a spiciness to it is gone at colder temperatures
very good flavor.  just right amount of spice.

It was on sale at a significant discount, so I picked it up, having never tasted it. Was my gamble worth it? 
YES.  On the nose, it smells toasty, almost fruity, a bit woody, and the distinct rye spiciness comes through. On the palate, much sweeter than expected. A mildly bitter finish. The spiciness of the rye really shines, thanks in part to the 46% abv. Not something I'd consider putting on ice, as I think the higher-than-average abv is this spirit's saving grace. It really gives it some character.
As someone who is only just discovering ryes as a viable competition to bourbon and scotch, I'll admit, this one hits the mark. I like it. I'd probably buy another bottle.
spicy with some nice caramel notes
Just bought this not too long ago. It’s a good rye but lacks the body of a Bulleit or Jim Beam for a daily drinker
Only had it on the rocks. Didn’t seem like anything special. Would give it 3.5 if possible.

From a distance, the nose is vanilla.  Closer up, the amber colored elixir is rye and barrel spice. 

On the palate, there’s more spice and some barrel char, as well as a bit of heat - a bit hotter than expected for its ABV. 

The finish is fairly long and spicy, with some vanilla as I breathe out through my nose.  

The palate is t up there with my favorite ryes like Knob Creek, Rittenhouse, and Crown Northern Harvest, but it gains some points back on finish.  Side note: benefits from ice.  3 stars.

dry spice, plenty of burn, some plasticy flavors that are a bit off putting. ice mellows the burn and plastic, but also makes it less spicy and more flat. drinkable neat, but probably better in a cocktail.
dang that's a lot of rye!
So smooth. A little too easy to drink. Sweet and spicy.
Light and young Rye, but good quality as you'd expect from MGP. A good daily pour
pretty bog standard rye. little bit if sourdough, little bit of spice. take it or leave it
Spicy, sweet, and full flavor all the way through.
The Rye adds that spice to the nose along with medicinal, oak, and floral notes.  The taste starts pretty spicy at first and then very sweet behind the tingle.

A good daily rye; good value for price. 
More heat on the nose than expected. 
Nice rounded spice on the palate with a slight char and caramel note finish.
Good. No burn. Goes down easy. After taste is lightly sweet

Definitely rye, spiciness and ethanol burn. The burn will stick with you for a while. This rye is definitely old-school and far surpasses Old Grandad in terms of complexity with rye and oak — and that blistering whiskey burn. Not as sweet as George Dickel.
Good similar to bullet rye with a little more smoke
Finishes spicy then sweet. Notes of cinnamon
Rich. Not a lot of bite. Best neat.
Spicy but smooth rye, still a strong alcohol kick. Good occasional change of pace from lighter, wheated bottles
Would probably be better with ice.
Good bite. Alcohol smell and bite. Good though. Slightly floral. No burn going down.
tasted at hundred north in gilbert. nose sweet. flavor flat and sweet hint of cinnamon no bite. not a fan.

My second rye whiskey and much better than the first (tempelton)
Smooth and a little sweet
Heavy char and a taste of dark fruit but well balanced rye. Strong lingering heat at 92%
grassy sweet grain nose. spice and then oak and smoke explode in the mouth. light body and quick finish with a little ethanol up the nose.  doesnt taste like a MGPI product, which is kinda too bad.

- cooking spices
- mint
- green leaves
- orange zest
- vegetable notes
Not much nose. Very clean. Lots of rye. Easy finish

Nose: Carmel, Rye, Earthy, Black Tea, Oak

Taste: Licorice/Rye Spice, Earthy, Leather, Oak, Carmel, Slight Vanilla
Not too peppery, smooth and a little sweet. Easy to drink.
Worth the entry level price. Good rye example.
Stong bodied rye. Ethanol-ish bite. Better used to mix than to drink straight.

Redemption Rye is yet another bottling of the 95% rye mash bill whiskey from MGP. Same as Bulliet, Dickel, and Templeton. And a few others I imagine that I don’t know yet. But while Bulliet and Dickel are solid ryes for the price point, Redemption leaves something to be desired. 

This whiskey is bottled at 46% ABV and is aged “not less than one year” in new charred oak barrels. Some write ups (including Distiller) have mentioned aging up to two and-a-half years. However, nowhere on the label does it claim to be “straight rye whiskey”, so I have my doubts. It may be a blend of barrels less than two years with a bit of slightly older stuff but in any case, this is a young whiskey and it shows. 

In the glass it’s a medium gold color, the first indication of its young age. Swirling leaves an oily coating but just a few slow legs. The nose is young grain whiskey, mild rye spice, a slight burn, and little else. There is a hint of fruitiness if you are patient enough to let it set a few. 

The palate is dry, minty, spicy oak. Little to no sweetness. The finish was actually unpleasant to me: just astringent, bitter oak tannins and an alcohol bite. This is not a good whiskey to sip neat. It does make a decent Manhattan; it’s dry, spicy character works well with the vermouth. This bottle was $24 locally. Not expensive, but considering the aforementioned Bulliet and Dickel can be had for the same or less, I will not bother with another one of these. 2.5/5. Cheers!
Meh....it’s just ok. Grab some wilderness trail rye instead.

Sorry I forget to write a review on this one. 
I picked up a bottle of this about a month ago. It’s a very full flavored rye that is an easy drinker. I do think it is my new favorite rye (sorry Bullet)

My first foray into an MGP 95/5 rye. 

Nose has some interesting elements; some floral notes (lilies maybe?), and remember those orange slice jelly candies with the sugar on them? Lots of that. Light toffee note underneath.

Palate opens with some brown sugar and nutmeg, but quickly switches to mint/eucalyptus mid way through. The finish is where this really excels. It’s a blend of nearly every kind of spice you can think of; black pepper, chilies, candied ginger, clove, spicy wood/barrel notes, and mustard seed. The only type of heat not in the finish is ethanol, which is gloriously absent. That spicy finish lingers for quite some time. Mouthfeel is nothing special, but does not detract. 

I would be remiss if I didn’t make mention of the fact that I have read other reviews on this whiskey and the results have been...not good. Lots of complaints of plastic and other off flavors, of which I got none. I don’t know what some of these reviewers tasted; it’s almost like they are drinking a completely different whiskey. Maybe I just got a good batch. Criminally underrated. Is it top notch? No. But is it solid for $27? Hell yes. Looking forward to trying more 95% ryes.
This was ok. It was not great.  The price point is right for mixing. I don't think it's a neat sipper.
Had in old fashioned; bulleit rye, simple syrup, aromatic & orange bitter, orange peel, luxardo cherry. Sweet orange flavor. Has a touch of spice on the finish. @ Twin Peaks Dallas
Had in MANhattan; redemption rye, carpano antica sweet vermouth, aromatic, luxardo syrup & orange bitter. Sweet orange herbal flavor. Sweet herbal finish. Dry herbal lingering flavor.
Very smooth! No bite on the finish. Excellent Rye
Yeast bready. Has some back heat. Smooth

Good aroma
Starts fairly smooth, little sweet slight alcohol mid rasp. Vanilla undertones. The Rye is evident as the rasp dissipates. Finishes with a whimper.
More mellow on the spice, slightly sweet.
Easy drinker like the taste at sip...nothing to special

Appearance: A polished copper color is what I view in this MGP rye. Thick watery legs dribble their way down the glass.

Nose: The nose is both sweet and savory with notes of oatmeal raisin cookies, cinnamon, honey, caramel, vanilla, light smoke, like the smell of residual smoke left on your jacket after a campfire, some eucalyptus, and toast. 

Taste: The palate was surprisingly pleasant and had notes of rye bread spiciness, dark chocolate, fennel/black licorice, and cinnamon.

Finish: There was a spicy then eventually mellow, lingering clove finish that was quite nice.

Thoughts: The Redemption brand is not what I would call a top shelfer, but it’s still  good. I prefer the rye to the bourbon personally, as I perceived more complexity and flavors than the bourbon. I don’t mind it one bit, and would recommend it if you haven’t tried it and are getting into ryes. Thanks, MGP. Cheers!

***Be Careful there are 1 Yr old bottles of this on the shelves!***
My first bottle turned out to be aged stated on the back 1 Yr and wasn't good; it had a lot of young sharp heat.
When I finally found another one that said aged 2 Yrs on the back label I decided to give it a second chance. I am glad to say the 2+ yr is much better and I am enjoying it. I am guessing they use wood staves to give this 95% MGP a lot of woodiness and set it apart from all the others. I taste good peach woodiness and nice amount of sweetness. It has a little extra heat, but I still enjoy sipping it neat. I may like this better than Bulliet. Redemption (and MGP of course) did a good job on this 2 Yr Rye - But make sure it is age stated 2 Yrs!

It's fine and all, but doubt I would get a 2nd bottle - probably better options out there. Not bad, but nothing special about it that I can place.  This is my 2nd tasting, after first opening it a couple months ago. I recall a more viscous, sweeter mouthfeel at that time. Maybe i'm just losing my mind?  Anyway, the next rye I get will be something different, and I'll probably still have some of this left to compare it against. No complaints considering the $$.
Great whistle clean cheap sipper. Solid cocktail base too

How anyone rated this whiskey over 50 points is completely beyond me. It tastes like sour milk, and goat vaginas. I tried it straight, and on the rocks...AWFUL. I mixed it with everything that I drink whiskey with...AWFUL. I feel bad saying this, because their bourbon is pretty good, and their wheated bourbon is one of my favorites. Don't waste your money on the rye.
Solid in an old fashioned or Manhattan.
Not terrible; maybe a little less refined than Bulleit. Strong alcohol presence up front with the usual notes of rye spice following behind.

Nose- light caramel toffee notes, orange zest, 

Taste- short sweet front end with a long spicy finish.

Aromas of oak, spice and orange. A touch of nail polish remover but not terribly unpleasant. Flavors are plenty of spice, oaky and caramel. Medium body, really coats the tongue in a slightly sticky way, pleasant warming burn that lingers and tingles the tongue. Great for the price, enjoyed neat, also perfect for cocktails, preferably Manhattans.
A bit of bite but clean finish. Best on rocks.  Grassy finish.
Light on the nose. Barely any noticeable smell. Very gentle after the initial burn.
